page.title: 07Wildlife in Charnwood
page.content: Plants reflect the altitude as well as the varied geology and soils of the area.Open moorland,hill pasture,sandy oak wood and marsh vegetation are all present while verges along sheltered lanes and motorway banks are rich in wild flowers.Viola palustris survives in Ulverscroft pond and bluebells in the woods also a little heather and bilberry on Beacon Hill.Badgers live there and among other of the larger animals are foxes,grey squirrels, stoats & weasels.On Beacon Hill too are newts also adders and these like all the wildlife there are protected.2 species of birds characteristic of the open slopes are the meadow pipit and reed bunting.Woodland birds here are warblers,nuthatch & great spotted woodpecker while in the winter siskin & redpoll are present in birchwood. Butterflies & insects are abundant.
